title: Quick Navigation
body: Select the "Return to Main Menu" button to go to the Main Menu, or select the "Next Page" button to continue to the next page.

title: Learning Objectives
body:
At the end of this course, you will be able to:

  • 1st objective
  • 2nd objective
  • add more if needed

title: How to Navigate Through the Course
displayTitle: How to Navigate Through the Course
body:
This course is designed to be interactive.

As you navigate through each page, you will see different interactive elements that contain more information or activities.

You will need to:

  • Open each accordion (expand/collapse)
  • Select each pin OR numbered button (delete if your course has no hot graphics)
  • Select each button

Activities, sections and images that have been viewed change to grey or have an added grey frame around them once activated; screen readers will announce them as â€œcompleted." 

The Page Level Progress at the top right of the page indicates your progress within that page.

You can use the down arrow to move to the next section.

Please take a moment to select the Open course resources button, located in the top right corner of this window, to access the following important tools:

  • Glossary: to consult any unfamiliar terms or acronyms
  • Resources: to view additional resources for this course
  • Search: to search words in this course

Select the Back link, located in the top left corner of this window, to return to the previously visited page.

Note: the hyperlinks open in a new tab; these links are accessible from the network.

title: How to Navigate Through the Course Graphic (hidden title)

_graphic.alt: Screenshot of navigation and Interactive Components icons.

title: Text - Title
body:
The text component does exactly what you think it should - display text. When using this component there are a couple of things to remember:

  1. When copying and pasting text from other text editors, you may unintentionally import other formatting along with the text. This can affect the way text is displayed and/or announced by a screen reader. Be sure to use the "paste as plain text" button in the Adapt text editor, or use another text editor to strip out the formatting before pasting it into Adapt.
  2. Text in languages other than the primary language must be marked up in the HTML code. Do not use the tool in the editor; it is not accessible. Use the Standard Issue Report and provide a list of all the instances of foreign language words (and their locations) to MeD so that they can properly mark-up the content. Exceptions to this rule are proper names, technical terms, words of indeterminate language, and words or phrases that have become part of the vernacular of the immediately surrounding text.

[Delete above text and replace with your own content]

title: Quick Navigation - Title
body:
This component MUST be the last component on every page of your course. Do not add a Tricle to this component since there is nothing that follows. [Include the instructions that follow, and delete this text to meet Adapt Best Practices guidlines]:

Select the "Previous Page" button to return to the previous page, select the "Return to Main Menu" button to return to the Main Menu, or select the "Next Page" button to continue to the next page.

title: Accordion - Title
body:
The Accordion Component displays a vertically stacked list of panels (called items on the Adapt backend) that acts as drawers for content. Selecting a panel toggles it open (while closing another - if another one is open).

Accordion panels can contain text and/or images. They are perfect for reducing the length of a page because of the way they collapse information. In some cases, the learner may be required to open all the panels. In these cases be sure to deselect the "option" checkbox in the Adapt backend, and add the text "(required)" to the pane Title. This way the learner knows they need to open that one in order to mark that section complete.

[Delete above text and replace with your own content]
instruction: Select or click on each title to learn more (on/about...). Open/read all X accordions to complete this section and continue.

title: Graphic, Text/Graphic Title - with combineblock
displayTitle: Graphic, Text/Graphic Display Title - with combineblock
body:
The graphic component displays images and other types of graphic content optimized for various devices. If your images are being viewed on a mobile device or tablet, the, smaller images will be displayed to accommodate those dimensions.

In accessibility terms, there are always two types of images:

  • Informative (alt text required)
  • Decorative (alt text must be left blank/empty)

If an image has information in it that is essential to understanding the content, that information must be included in the alternative (alt) text. If the image(s) take away from, or distract from the learning material, you must leave the alt text empty (blank).

Note:  The Block container for these two components has the "combineblock" class applied to it. The "combineblock" class is used to combine two (or more) blocks so that they appear as one block. It can only be used on the second block (or any subsequent blocks), but not on the first block. 

[Delete above text and replace with your own content]
instruction: Use 1200 pixels wide for a full-size image

title: Graphical Multiple Choice - Title
body:
The Graphical Multiple Choice Question presents the learner with a series of images to select from. The Item text label for each image is displayed on the screen.  

Things to consider when setting up this component:

  1. Ensure you leave the alt text empty, as the image description is already available in the answer option text below and after each graphic. It can be distracting when it is repeated twice for some learners.
  2. Because graphical multiple choice questions tend to be better suited to sighted learners, it is important to create very accurate descriptions of each image.

Note: The Learner's Pick option is not yet ready to be used with graphical multiple choice type questions. To ensure your answer feedback resembles the format you chose for the other question types, consider using the same style that has been used for this component, as it mimics the appearance of the Learner's Pick option in the Project Settings.

[Delete question text and answer options, and replace with your own.]
instruction: Select one answer and then select Submit to complete this question

_items.feedback: You selected the graphic of a red balloon. That is the correct answer.

_items.text: Graphic of a green puzzle piece - 400 by 400.

_feedback.correct: Congratulations! You chose the red balloon. That is the correct answer.

title: Hot Graphic - Title
body:
The Hot Graphic is an image that you place graphic "pins" on, in order to provide more information about that area of the image. It is especially useful for maps, as in this case, or for referencing plotted points on a chart or diagram. Search "Adapt Starter Course..." in the Adapt Media library, if you wish to use the pins seen here.

title: Hot Grid - Title
body:
The Hot Grid component displays images in a gallery format. Each image can be selected to open a popup dialogue box with more information. Hot grids are best suited when you want to display a gallery of images, with more information about each one made available when selected.

[Delete text above and below images, and replace with your own content]

title: Matching Question - Title
body:
The Matching Questions Component presents the learner with a question and a dropdown list of possible answers.

The Matching Questions Component works well with the Learner's Pick option which can be activated from the Project Settings are of the Adapt backend.

Note: To meet accessibility guidelines it is necessary to limit the number of question options to only one (even though you are able to add more in the backend of Adapt). Learners with cognitive disabilities may have difficulty retaining information if presented with too many options at once

[Delete question text and answer options, and replace with your own.]
instruction: Select one answer and then select Submit to complete this question

_items.text: If you type your question here, in the Matching Items Text field, your question will appear below the Component instructions. This is the best option at this time.

_options.text: This is clearly the best answer.
This is the second best answer.
This is the third best answer.
This is the least best answer.

_incorrect.final:
Sorry that is incorrect.

The correct answer is "This is clearly the best answer".

title: Narrative - Title
body:
Like a PowerPoint presentation, the Narrative component instructs users to select arrow buttons to move backwards or forwards through a series of slides. This format is well suited to information that requires presenting in sequential order, or for images that do not require selecting for more information.

The MeD accessibility team recommends a minimum of 2 and a maximum of 8 slides per Narrative component.

[Delete existing content and replace with your own images and text]
instruction: Select or click on the arrow buttons (next/previous) to find out more (about ...). Open/read all 6 slides to complete this section and continue.

title: Multiple Choice - Title
body:
The Multiple Choice Questions Component presents the learner with a question and a list of possible answers. The designer can add as many answer options as desired.

This component works best when it is used with the Learner's Pick option, which can be activated in the Project Settings section of the Adapt backend.

title: Open Text Input - Title
body:
The Open Text Input Component presents the learner with a text input form that allows them to enter a freeform answer up to a maximum number of characters. This component is well suited for questions that do not have an exact answer, but still require thinking and writing, such as a self-reflection question. 

Note: There are some known issues which we are working on. Use with caution.

[Delete the preceding text and replace with your question.]
instruction: Please type your answer in the input box below. Please do not use more than 500 characters.
modelAnswer: Provide the correct answer here to give there learner something to compare with their own answer.

title: Slider - Title
body:
The Slider Component presents learners with a question that can be answered using a scale and a range of numbers. The scale can be labelled at either end, with text the defines the context. The correct answer can be an exact point on the scale, or fall within a range.â€¯ 

[Delete all text and type or paste your question here]
instruction: Move the slider to select one answer and then select Submit to complete this question.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
You have selected the CORRECT answer(s).

The answer is: 7

_incorrect.final:
Unfortunately, you have selected the INCORRECT answer.

The answer is: 7

title: Media - Title
body:
The Media Component is used to present learners with a short video or audio clip. 

Provide a short description here to explain what this video is about to the learner. This will give learners who learn using other means the option to skip it if they want to.

body:

good luck!

title: Quick Navigation
body:
To access the main menu, select the "Return to Main Menu" button or the "Home" button located in the upper left corner of the page in the navigation section.

If you have completed the course, close this window and complete the evaluation.

title: Hot Grid - Title
body:
The Hot Grid component displays images in a gallery format. Each image can be selected to open a popup dialogue box with more information. Hot grids are best suited when you want to display a gallery of images, with more information about each one made available when selected.

[Delete text above and below images, and replace with your own content]

title: Narrative - Title
body:
Like a PowerPoint presentation, the Narrative component instructs users to select arrow buttons to move backwards or forwards through a series of slides. This format is well suited to information that requires presenting in sequential order, or for images that do not require selecting for more information.

The MeD accessibility team recommends a minimum of 2 and a maximum of 8 slides per Narrative component.

[Delete existing content and replace with your own images and text]
instruction: Select or click on the arrow buttons (next/previous) to find out more (about ...). Open/read all 6 slides to complete this section and continue.

_items.title: Slide 01 - Narrative Component - Text
_items.body: The Narrative Display Title and Narrative Strapline Text must be exact matches. The Narrative Strapline Text replaces the Narrative Display Title when the screen is magnified to 400%.

title: Media - Title
body:
The Media Component is used to present learners with a short video or audio clip. 

Provide a short description here to explain what this video is about to the learner. This will give learners who learn using other means the option to skip it if they want to.

[Delete above text and replace with your own content]
instruction: Select the button to start the video and/or select the "Show transcript" button to read the narration.

title: Text - Title
body:
The text component does exactly what you think it should - display text. When using this component there are a couple of things to remember:

  1. When copying and pasting text from other text editors, you may unintentionally import other formatting along with the text. This can affect the way text is displayed and/or announced by a screen reader. Be sure to use the "paste as plain text" button in the Adapt text editor, or use another text editor to strip out the formatting before pasting it into Adapt.
  2. Text in languages other than the primary language must be marked up in the HTML code. Do not use the tool in the editor; it is not accessible. Use the Standard Issue Report and provide a list of all the instances of foreign language words (and their locations) to MeD so that they can properly mark-up the content. Exceptions to this rule are proper names, technical terms, words of indeterminate language, and words or phrases that have become part of the vernacular of the immediately surrounding text.

[Delete above text and replace with your own content]

title: Accordion - Title
body:
The Accordion Component displays a vertically stacked list of panels (called items on the Adapt backend) that acts as drawers for content. Selecting a panel toggles it open (while closing another - if another one is open).

Accordion panels can contain text and/or images. They are perfect for reducing the length of a page because of the way they collapse information. In some cases, the learner may be required to open all the panels. In these cases be sure to deselect the "option" checkbox in the Adapt backend, and add the text "(required)" to the pane Title. This way the learner knows they need to open that one in order to mark that section complete.

[Delete above text and replace with your own content]
instruction: Select or click on each title to learn more (on/about...). Open/read all X accordions to complete this section and continue.

title: Graphic, Text/Graphic Title - with combineblock
body:
The graphic component displays images and other types of graphic content optimized for various devices. If your images are being viewed on a mobile device or tablet, the, smaller images will be displayed to accommodate those dimensions.

In accessibility terms, there are always two types of images:

  • Informative (alt text required)
  • Decorative (alt text must be left blank/empty)

If an image has information in it that is essential to understanding the content, that information must be included in the alternative (alt) text. If the image(s) take away from, or distract from the learning material, you must leave the alt text empty (blank).

Note:  The Block container for these two components has the "combineblock" class applied to it. The "combineblock" class is used to combine two (or more) blocks so that they appear as one block. It can only be used on the second block (or any subsequent blocks), but not on the first block. 

[Delete above text and replace with your own content]
instruction: Use 1200 pixels wide for a full-size image

title: Text - Half Width Title
body:
This is an example of a text component at half width. Half width can be used with any other component. It is used here for demonstration purposes.

Important! If you are using two (2) interactive components per block (this example does not use interactive components), they MUST have Page Level Progress assigned to them, and NOT the Block Level Display title, in order to remain accessible.

[Delete above text and replace with your own content]

title: Graphic - Half Width Title
body:
This is an example of a graphic component at half width. Half width can be used with any other component. It is used here for demonstration purposes.

Important! If you are using two (2) interactive components per block (this example does not use interactive components), they MUST have Page Level Progress assigned to them, and NOT the Block Level Display title, in order to remain accessible.
instruction: Use a 600 pixel wide image for half-width components. Delete this image and replace withÂ your own.

title: Quick Navigation - Title
body:
This component MUST be the last component on every page of your course. Do not add a Tricle to this component since there is nothing that follows. [Include the instructions that follow, and delete this text to meet Adapt Best Practices guidlines]:

Select the "Previous Page" button to return to the previous page, select the "Return to Main Menu" button to return to the Main Menu, or select the "Next Page" button to continue to the next page.

title: Graphical Multiple Choice - Title
body:
The Graphical Multiple Choice Question presents the learner with a series of images to select from. The Item text label for each image is displayed on the screen.  

Things to consider when setting up this component:

  1. Ensure you leave the alt text empty, as the image description is already available in the answer option text below and after each graphic. It can be distracting when it is repeated twice for some learners.
  2. Because graphical multiple choice questions tend to be better suited to sighted learners, it is important to create very accurate descriptions of each image.

Note: The Learner's Pick option is not yet ready to be used with graphical multiple choice type questions. To ensure your answer feedback resembles the format you chose for the other question types, consider using the same style that has been used for this component, as it mimics the appearance of the Learner's Pick option in the Project Settings.

[Delete question text and answer options, and replace with your own.]
instruction: Select one answer and then select Submit to complete this question

_graphic.alt: Orange graphic of a cheese-like planet

_items.text: Orange graphic of a cheese-like planet - 400 by 400
_items.feedback: You selected the graphic of the orange cheese-like planet. That is incorrect. The correct answer is the red balloon.

_graphic.alt: Graphic of a red balloon - 400 by 400

_items.text: Graphic of a red balloon - 400 by 400
_items.feedback: You selected the graphic of a red balloon. That is the correct answer.

_graphic.alt: Blue graphic of a earth globe - 400 by 400

_items.text: Blue graphic of a earth globe - 400 by 400
_items.feedback: You selected the blue graphic of an earth globe. Sorry that is incorrect. The correct answer is the red balloon.

_graphic.alt: Graphic of a green puzzle piece - 400 by 400

_items.text: Graphic of a green puzzle piece - 400 by 400.
_items.feedback: You selected the graphic of a green puzzle piece. Sorry that is incorrect. The correct answer is the red balloon.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct: Congratulations! You chose the red balloon. That is the correct answer.

title: Matching Question - Title
body:
The Matching Questions Component presents the learner with a question and a dropdown list of possible answers.

The Matching Questions Component works well with the Learner's Pick option which can be activated from the Project Settings are of the Adapt backend.

Note: To meet accessibility guidelines it is necessary to limit the number of question options to only one (even though you are able to add more in the backend of Adapt). Learners with cognitive disabilities may have difficulty retaining information if presented with too many options at once

[Delete question text and answer options, and replace with your own.]
instruction: Select one answer and then select Submit to complete this question

_items.text: If you type your question here, in the Matching Items Text field, your question will appear below the Component instructions. This is the best option at this time.

_options.text: This is clearly the best answer.
This is the second best answer.
This is the third best answer.
This is the least best answer.

_incorrect.final:
Sorry that is incorrect.

The correct answer is "This is clearly the best answer".

title: Multiple Choice - Title
body:
The Multiple Choice Questions Component presents the learner with a question and a list of possible answers. The designer can add as many answer options as desired.

This component works best when it is used with the Learner's Pick option, which can be activated in the Project Settings section of the Adapt backend.

[Delete question text and answer options, and replace with your own.]
instruction: Select one answer and then select Submit to complete this question.

_items.feedback: Duis aute irure dolor in reprehenderit in voluptate velit esse cillum dolore eu fugiat nulla pariatur. Excepteur sint occaecat cupidatat non proident, sunt in culpa qui officia deserunt mollit anim id est laborum.
That is incorrect. The correct answer is A.
That is incorrect. The correct answer is A.
That is incorrect. The correct answer is A.

_incorrect.final: Unfortunately, you have selected the INCORRECT answer. The correct answer is A.

title: Open Text Input - Title
body:
The Open Text Input Component presents the learner with a text input form that allows them to enter a freeform answer up to a maximum number of characters. This component is well suited for questions that do not have an exact answer, but still require thinking and writing, such as a self-reflection question. 

Note: There are some known issues which we are working on. Use with caution.

[Delete the preceding text and replace with your question.]
instruction: Please type your answer in the input box below. Please do not use more than 500 characters.
modelAnswer: Provide the correct answer here to give there learner something to compare with their own answer.

title: Slider - Title
body:
The Slider Component presents learners with a question that can be answered using a scale and a range of numbers. The scale can be labelled at either end, with text the defines the context. The correct answer can be an exact point on the scale, or fall within a range.â€¯ 

[Delete all text and type or paste your question here]
instruction: Move the slider to select one answer and then select Submit to complete this question.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
You have selected the CORRECT answer(s).

The answer is: 7

_incorrect.final:
Unfortunately, you have selected the INCORRECT answer.

The answer is: 7

title: Accordion - Title
body:
The Accordion Component displays a vertically stacked list of panels (called items on the Adapt backend) that acts as drawers for content. Selecting a panel toggles it open (while closing another - if another one is open).

Accordion panels can contain text and/or images. They are perfect for reducing the length of a page because of the way they collapse information. In some cases, the learner may be required to open all the panels. In these cases be sure to deselect the "option" checkbox in the Adapt backend, and add the text "(required)" to the pane Title. This way the learner knows they need to open that one in order to mark that section complete.

[Delete above text and replace with your own content]

title: Graphical Long Description
body: The Accordion Component displays a vertically stacked list of panels (called items on the Adapt backend) that acts as drawers for content. Selecting a panel toggles it open (while closing another - if another one is open).
instruction: Select or click on each title to learn more (on/about...). Open/read all X accordions to complete this section and continue.
